verses.text: In the second year of King Darius, in the sixth month, on the first day of the month, the word of the LORD came by the hand of Haggai the prophet to Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and to Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest, saying:
verses.comment: This opening sets the historical context for the prophecy. The term 'the word of the LORD came by the hand of Haggai' reveals the prophetic office as a mediator between God and his people. The mention of both the governor and high priest underscores God’s concern for both spiritual and civic leadership, hinting at the integrated structure of authority among God’s people.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: These people say, ‘The time has not yet come to rebuild the house of the LORD.’
verses.comment: The phrase 'the LORD of hosts' emphasizes God's supreme authority over all powers. The people's excuse to delay building the Temple reveals spiritual apathy. The Temple represents God’s dwelling among his people—a theme later fulfilled in Christ, the true Temple (see John 2:19–21).

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came by the hand of Haggai the prophet:
verses.comment: Repetition of this formula highlights the authority and reliability of Haggai’s message, as it comes directly from God.

verses.text: Is it a time for you yourselves to dwell in your paneled houses, while this house lies in ruins?
verses.comment: The rebuke exposes the contrast between the people’s comfort and neglect of God’s house. There is a subtle call here to prioritize God’s presence and worship above personal desires—a recurring message throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Now therefore, thus says the LORD of hosts: Consider your ways.
verses.comment: ‘Consider your ways’ invites reflection and examination of heart, a practice urged elsewhere in Scripture (Lamentations 3:40). This call to ongoing self-examination is a spiritual discipline for all believers.

verses.text: You have sown much, but harvested little. You eat, but you never have enough. You drink, but you never have your fill. You clothe yourselves, but no one is warm. And the one who earns wages does so to put them into a bag with holes.
verses.comment: This verse demonstrates the consequences of neglecting God for self-interest: spiritual and material dissatisfaction. These curses echo Deuteronomy 28’s warnings, showing covenant continuity. Blessing flows from rightly ordered priorities towards God.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: Consider your ways.
verses.comment: Repetition of this command increases its urgency. Self-examination is a key biblical value, deeply tied to genuine repentance and growth.

verses.text: Go up to the mountains and bring wood and build the house, so that I may take pleasure in it and be glorified, says the LORD.
verses.comment: God desires outward acts of obedience (action: build the house) that flow from a heart that seeks to glorify Him. The Temple, as God’s dwelling, prefigures how God will ultimately dwell with his people fully (see Revelation 21:3), realized in the coming of Christ.

verses.text: You looked for much, but it came to little. And when you brought it home, I blew it away. Why? declares the LORD of hosts. Because my house lies in ruins, while each of you busies himself with his own house.
verses.comment: Here, the Lord directly connects the people’s unfruitfulness to their neglect of His dwelling. Prioritizing God’s house brings order and blessing to the rest of life, a foundational biblical principle.

verses.text: Therefore the heavens above you have withheld the dew, and the earth has withheld its produce.
verses.comment: The agricultural hardship is not accidental, but a direct result of disobedience. This recalls covenant blessings and curses, emphasizing God’s sovereignty over creation and daily life.

verses.text: And I have called for a drought on the land and the hills, on the grain, the new wine, the oil, on what the ground brings forth, on man and beast, and on all their labors.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is comprehensive, affecting every aspect of life. This reminds believers that all prosperity is ultimately from the Lord, and the worship of God takes precedence over material pursuits.

verses.text: Then Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, and Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest, with all the remnant of the people, obeyed the voice of the LORD their God, and the words of Haggai the prophet, as the LORD their God had sent him. And the people feared the LORD.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the importance of both lay and priestly leaders, as well as the obedience of the whole community. Their reverence and obedience show the model response to God’s instruction. Obedience and proper reverence are marks of authentic community and worship.

verses.text: Then Haggai, the messenger of the LORD, gave the people this message from the LORD: 'I am with you,' declares the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s promise, 'I am with you,' is a recurring biblical assurance to His people. This presence is realized most fully in Jesus Christ, Emmanuel, 'God with us' (Matthew 1:23). The divine presence is the foundation of true worship.

verses.text: And the LORD stirred up the spirit of Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and the spirit of Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest, and the spirit of all the remnant of the people. And they came and worked on the house of the LORD of hosts, their God,
verses.comment: God initiates the renewal of His people by stirring their hearts, demonstrating that spiritual movement always begins with divine grace. The inclusion of both office-bearers and people reveals the deep unity of the faithful, acting together, which echoes the spiritual principle of the Church as the unified Body of believers.

verses.text: on the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month, in the second year of King Darius.
verses.comment: This concluding note roots the narrative in history, emphasizing the reliability of the account. The careful recording of dates reinforces the importance of God’s action at specific times, ultimately foreshadowing significant moments of salvation history.
